title: I have a bankruptcy, will my boyfriend and I be declined for a house rental application based on my credit?
question: I have a recent bankruptcy, my boyfriend has excellent credit and a substantial savings account. We are applying for a new lease and are both required to fill out applications to both be named on the lease as joint tenants.
answers:
You shouldn't be turned down ... but some landlords are not very bright.
If it's a problem, let the boyfriend be the only one on the hook.

There's no rule or law that a bankrutpcy will or won't prevent you from being able to rent; these are individual lender/landlord decisions. I would talk to the landlord or management company and explain that although you've filed for bankrutpcy, you have the present ability to pay the rent and if necessary, you can offer a greater security deposit becuase given the savings account.

You may be better off with a private property owner as opposed to a corporate leasing company in that regard as the latter may be less flexible. Best of luck.

Probably not. Landlords care more that you have not had any unlawful detainer actions (evictions). Indeed, if you have discharged your debts in bankruptcy or settled your debts and they are all paid (even if not paid timely), then at least the landlord will know that you will probably have the funds to make consistent rent payments. The thing that landlords like least are having to collect back rent, deal with bounced rent checks, and evictions. If the tenant has no debt collection agency to settle with or outstanding debt collection judgment, the tenant will likely be okay with making the monthly rent.
